quoteFirst: The poor's advocate had begged Lenette (about a
quoteLast: in the afternoon) not to go on working herself to death, and never to mind bothering about any supper, as he was going to be miserly for once, save himself a supper tonight, and sup upon eighteen penn'orth of pastry: but the busy soul kept running about brushing and sweeping, and by six o'clock they were both lying resting in the leather arms of--a big easy chair (for he had no flesh and she no bones), and looking around them with that expression of tranquil happiness which you may see in children while eating, at the room in its state of mathematical
title:

quoteFirst: The others, the 4th and 5th Leicesters, lost themselves on the way and wandered blasphemous among trenches. “The consequent confusion was deplorable.” The Battalion were chaperoning themselves and others from half-past ten to a
quoteLast: in the morning. Then began the mile and a half of nightmare-like crawl up the seven-foot-deep communication-trench, whose sides took strange Egyptian-desert-like colours in the dawn-light, and whose bends and windings bewildered all sense of direction.
title: The Irish Guards in the Great War, Volume 2 (of 2)

quoteFirst: When the man in the yellow coat had thrown the agent off his track, he redoubled his pace, not without turning round many a time to assure himself that he was not being followed. At a
quoteLast: , that is to say, when night was fully come, he passed in front of the theatre of the Porte Saint-Martin, where _The Two Convicts_ was being played that day. This poster, illuminated by the theatre lanterns, struck him; for, although he was walking rapidly, he halted to read it.

quoteFirst: Then, at a
quoteLast: , Miss Blow’s voice brought him back from his security. She called him by name from the back door of the barrack. Then he joined Miss Blow and the other ladies in the day room.

quoteFirst: David could not be spared to go with them, but all the children had been taught to drive, and even Bobby had a firm hand on the reins, and knew the rules of the road as well as many a more experienced coachman; and I think, too, that Pixie had a sense of her responsibilities, and could be trusted not to get the wheel locked with a passing waggon, or to race too furiously down a steep hill, whatever feats her drivers might urge her to perform. The pony and trap were put up for the day at a quiet little inn midway between the two schools, and were always waiting for the children by a
quoteLast: , when, like the traditional donkey, they joyfully turned their noses towards home again.
title: A Terrible Tomboy
author: Brazil, Angela, 1869-1947; Tenison, N. (Nell Marion), 1867-1953 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Bowling fired a gun across her bows, whereupon she replied with a broadside, which did a little damage and wounded three men; but a couple of well-aimed rounds, at 750 yards, from the privateer’s 9·4-in. guns, brought the French captain to his senses; and at a
quoteLast: , being on fire and having thirty men killed or wounded by the bursting of a shell in his battery, he surrendered. Lieutenant Tripper and fifty men went on board and took possession; 150 of the cruiser’s crew were for safety’s sake removed into the _Mary Rose_, and the _Paraguay_ having got into Cherbourg and given the alarm, Bowling and his two prizes made the best of their way to Plymouth, where they dropped anchor soon after noon on Saturday, May 9th.
title: The captain of the "Mary Rose"
author: Clowes, W. Laird (William Laird), Sir, 1856-1905; De Martino, Edoardo, 1838-1912 [Illustrator]; Jane, Fred T. (Frederick Thomas), 1865-1916 [Illustrator]
